subject: Re: [junit] Re: the humbug dialog box,
msgSnippet: ... Dave Astels book, A Practical Guide to Test-Driven Development, develops such an example (and is a fine book besides). Not being a big Swing programmer
messageBody:
Shane Mingins wrote:
>
> --- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> > Agreed, however, when I don't know what to do, I
> > minimize the amount of
> > untested code, which is what a thin GUI is all
> > about. I don't think you
> > can argue that this is a bad practice. One has to
> > start somewhere.
> >
>
> Hi J.B.
>
> Do you have, or know of, a Java Swing example
> illustrating this separation structure? A picture
> paints a thousand words, but code is so much easier to
> read :-)
>
> I (and another poster on java-gui-testing) were
> interested in seeing a working example to better
> understand this.

Dave Astels' book, A Practical Guide to Test-Driven Development,
develops such an example (and is a fine book besides). Not being a big
Swing programmer myself, I don't have other examples handy. I am about
to start programming in Windows Forms/C#, so I will likely re-learn
these lessons in the key of C# quite soon.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
